title: Philosophy of Science for the Study of Politics
xlist:
Same As: PLSC 332, section 01
Same As: EP&E 299, section 01
description: In this seminar we consider a number of debates in the philosophy of science from the perspective of the study of politics. The principal focus is on the human sciences, but there is some attention to the natural sciences and to unified views of the sciences. Among the topics covered are theories of causation; hypothesis testing and falsification; methodological individualism and holism; induction, deduction, modeling, and prediction; the fact/value problem; the relations among description, explanation, and interpretation; and, more generally, debates about empiricism, realism, the social construction of reality, and the proper ambition of social science. Among the authors discussed are David Hume, A.J. Ayer, Max Weber, Karl Popper, Carl Hempel, Thomas Kuhn, Imre Lakatos, J.L. Austin, Ludwig Wittgenstein, JÃ¼rgen Habermas, Quentin Skinner, Roy Bhaskar, Thomas Nagel, Peter Winch, Richard Miller, Jon Elster, and Daniel Kahneman. Students have the option of writing two ten-page papers, a research paper, or a final exam.
